title: How to prepare for an essay writing competition (national level) - Quora

response.answer_text: Firstly, know the rules and, if you can, the topics, and a little about the judges. Read the works of other winners of the competition, prior to you. Know the goal of the essay. Is the goal to convince, or entertain, or refute? Is it to read an existing piece and dissect? Is it an opinion piece? Creative writing? If you can, know! The writing skills are going to have to be honed already. You’ll need to know how to use juxtaposition, allusion, and use grammar and punctuation to create flow — so nothing new there. Clarity and directness is good in most cases, but if these judges are from academia, then you may want to leverage more complex sentence forms in the body of work. I usually don’t advocate complexity. Clarity is much more powerful. Secondly, whether you read up on topics that you know are included in the competition, or simply cover a lot of current affairs from various magazines and books, try to read in a well-rounded way. That is, don’t read only Western writers’ opinions; don’t read only white writers’ opinions; don’t read only male writers’ opinions. You’ll get a full and rich context if you read across a variety of diverse writers. And don’t automatically discount an opinion different than your own, either. If a disabled woman writer is expressing an opinion in her book or magazine / newspaper article, do yourself a favour and take it seriously. Some people will automatically downplay, or even discount the experiences and opinions of diverse writers like these. Don’t you fall into that trap. Read in good faith until and unless the writer begins to prove you should do otherwise. Final point — because there have been other good points for you to get to in this thread — have fun! You’re not going to win a competition if you’re not memorable. To be memorable it helps to be authentic and speak your (well-researched) mind. It’s hard to do that until you’ve formulated an opinion on all you’ve read, and unless you relax and have fun writing about the topic. Readers can feel the difference in the writing, and you will too. If the topic isn’t one that anyone could have fun writing, cover it factually, but don’t forget to humanize as you do so. Demographers can be guilty of forgetting this, sometimes. One doesn’t want to run the risk of treating the people behind the numbers like chess pieces, or worse, brood mares. I’m not sure this advice will come close to covering the prep work you’ll need to do. Maybe you’re looking for advice more like ‘Carry several pens’. ‘Be ready to respond with heroic couplets in carmen figuratum’, though… I’d probably get a kick out of that, not gonna lie! But, generally speaking, think about the topic you’ve got deeply and creatively. Innovate. And leave nothing on the table. After you’re done, read it back and make changes as needed, to grammar, punctuation (for flow), and add what’s missing. Clarify what’s unclear. After you’ve done your best, let it go. You can’t go into the minds of the judges and make them choose your work, after all. But you can make your work hard not to choose. I hope this helps!

This kind of depends… do you know the prompt? If so the prep is fairly straight forward-looking research and educate yourself to the best of your ability on the subject and organize with a strong universal thesis and strong points. I would also advise against the traditional 5 paragraph format, unless regulations specify otherwise. But, as the likelihood is that you do not know your prompt, I would simply advise looking up on depth prompts and write. In that manner you will be able to create synaptic responses to that specific trigger (the essay prompt), create easier neurological pathways to allow the information and organization to flow, and heighten your vocabulary and sentence sttucture. Essentially, practice will make perfect in this case. I'm sorry I couldn't be more help.
